description:
Etheostoma cragini, commonly known as the Arkansas darter, is a small freshwater fish species belonging to the family Percidae. It is native to the central United States, found primarily in the Ozark and Ouachita mountain regions of Arkansas, Missouri, and Oklahoma.

The Arkansas darter is a small, slender fish typically measuring around 5-7 cm in length. It has a distinct coloration pattern, with a brownish-olive dorsal surface and a pale, yellowish-white ventral region. Distinctive features include a large, terminal mouth, and a long, spinous dorsal fin.

This species prefers clear, cool, and well-oxygenated streams and small to medium-sized rivers with gravel or rocky substrates. They are often found in riffles and runs, where they feed on a variety of small invertebrates, including insects, crustaceans, and mollusks.

The Arkansas darter is considered a habitat specialist, as it requires specific environmental conditions to thrive. It is sensitive to changes in water quality, sedimentation, and habitat alterations, making it a valuable indicator species for the overall health of the aquatic ecosystem.

Due to its limited distribution and conservation concerns, the Arkansas darter is classified as a threatened or endangered species in several states within its native range. Conservation efforts aim to protect and restore its critical habitats to ensure the long-term survival of this unique freshwater fish.
